Name: Cedrol
Description: Cedrol is a cedrane sesquiterpenoid and a tertiary alcohol.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) EFSA; The EFSA Journal ON-978: 1-85 (2009). Available from, as of July 1, 2015: https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/scdocs/doc/978.pdf
plant_concentrations.Value: Cedrol is reported to occur in European calamus (Acorus calamus var calamus; Acoraceae) at 1,900 mg/kg and in cinnamon (Cinnamomum verum) at concentrations up to 100 mg/kg(1).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) NTP; Summary Data for Chemical Selection, Cedarwood Oil (8000-27-9) June 20, 2002. Available from, as of July 2, 2015: https://ntp.niehs.nih.gov/ntp/htdocs/chem_background/exsumpdf/cedarwood_oil_508.pdf (2) Verdan MH et al; Nat Prod Commun 9: 1535-37 (2014) (3) Song WF et al; Zhong Yao Cai 34: 1725-27 (2011)
plant_concentrations.Value: The volatile oil from Western juniper has been reported to contain 15-40% cedrol(1). Texas and Virginia cedarwood oils are reported to contain 19.0 and 15.8% cedrol respectively(1). Cedrol was detected in the chemical constituents of the flowering plants of Sinningia canescens and Sinningia warmingii(2). Analysis of the essential oil of Dalbergia odorifera (fragrant rosewood) found cedrol at a concentration of 1.65%(3).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) USDA; Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. Cedrol. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of July 2, 2015: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/
